text: [Music]
you know I mean right now we have

in our country's most economically

college campuses they Source top

evidence that this is an unbelievably

in America but it is another to

but meeting them you realize these are

hardworking kids and I think they bring

of all we need every additional person

take this
on I mean actually today I'm probably
more passionate about what we do than

honestly it's just what I've learned

and and alumni and I continue to see
more more and more evidence of the
possibility of making real progress you
know so you know there there are just
growing numbers of our teachers who who
really just you know you see them
literally changing the course of their
kids lives I think about a woman who um
whose classroom I visited last year
named Gillette Hughes who uh started
working with a class of fourth graders
who were on the first grade level in
reading and she was talking about how
shocked she was to realize that really
they were reading on the first grade
level and she ended up if you know
moving them forward two years in a
year's time in her first year in the
classroom and then convinced the
principal to let her teach the same kids
the second year so in that second year
she moved them another two years of
progress and then realized I mean she
had literally put them where they should
be in fifth grade but then they were
going to go to this nearby middle school
so she ended up working with the parents
and getting them into some of the most
selective middle schools in the in the
city in New York um and I just think
gosh you know I mean this one woman at
age 22 or 23 literally changed the
trajectory of her kids and and I could
tell you know hundreds of of examples
like that and then you know I mentioned
earlier Chris barbick who you know I
mean actually if you look at the list of
100 top high schools in America um two
of the schools on the list and and two
of the 11 schools who reach primarily
low-income kids um are run by and were
started by Teach for America alumni one
is Chris barik's High School in Houston
which is the only High School in Houston
on the list and the other is school in a
rural area in the Rio Grande Valley in

what those two guys and the many who
work with them have literally turned
educational inequity on its head I mean
you're actually on an absolute scale not
even factoring in the socioeconomics of
the kids you're off going to their high
schools than going to almost any other
High School in the city in the state of

like those are the people who are
showing us this can be done it is simply
a question of Will and and now seeing
some of our alums say you know what
we're going to prove this can be done on
the system level and and from Michelle
and her colleagues who are taking on the

who um runs the the alternative school
district in in New York City which
serves 50,000 kids who have for one

traditional system I some of the hardest
to reach kids and you see what she has

think wow you know every year I gain
more and more evidence just from among
our folks that this is possible not only

that's what keeps me you know going and
